alert.note: Alert for Mason (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued December 05 at 4:32PM PST until further notice by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Washington... Satsop River Near Satsop affecting Grays Harbor County. Cowlitz River At Randle affecting Lewis County. Nisqually River Near National affecting Lewis and Pierce Counties. Chehalis River Above Grand Mound affecting Grays Harbor and Thurston Counties. Skokomish River At Potlatch affecting Mason County. ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Washington... Newaukum River Near Chehalis affecting Lewis County. Chehalis River Above Doty affecting Lewis County. .Rain will slowly taper off over night and move out of the area Wednesday. For the Olympic Peninsula Region...including La Push, McDonald Bridge, Sequim, Potlatch, Satsop, Montesano...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the South West Region...including Mud Mtn. Dam Outflow, R Street Bridge, South Prairie, Fairfax, Orting, Puyallup, National, McKenna, Rainier, Packwood, Randle, Mayfield Dam...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Chehalis River Basin Region...including Bucoda, Centralia, Chehalis, Doty, Centralia, Grand Mound, Porter...Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. This approaches the flood of record. * WHERE...Skokomish River at Potlatch. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 17.5 feet, the Skokomish River will cause moderate flooding, with deep and quick flood waters inundating some residential areas, many roads, and much of the farm land in the Skokomish Valley. Inundated roads include the Skokomish Valley road, Bourgault Road West, Purdy Cutoff Road, and Highway 106. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:00 PM PST Tuesday the stage was 17.9 feet. - Flood stage is 16.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 4:00 PM PST Tuesday was 18.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 17.1 feet Sunday afternoon. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 18.16 feet on 12/03/2007. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by this evening at 1145 PM PST.
